 Summary This paper focuses on one of the factors thought to be important in explaining changes in fertility over time, namely the schooling of children. Theory predicts that it exerts a negative effect on parental fertility. The mechanisms by which this relationship occurs at the micro-level have been elaborated by Becker in this quantity-quality trade-off model, and by Caldwell in his intergenerational transfer model. In the Becker model, an increase in quantity decreases demand for quality, both through the shadow income constraint, and by raising the shadow price of quality. An increase in the demand for quality decreases the demand for close quantity by a similar mechanism. Although quantity and quality need not be close substitutes, an increase in the demand for one will decrease the demand for the other. In the Caldwell model, fertility decline sets in only when the direction of net wealth flow changes from children to parents, over to parents to children. The (mass) education of children is seen as a primary determinant in changing the direction of the wealth flow between generations. First, the child's potential for work both inside and outside the family is reduced; not only because of the hours needed for school attendance and homework, but also because of the changing attitudes of the child and family toward traditional work at home. Second, education increases the direct costs of children to the family. The institution of mass education also changes the position of the child in the family and in society, and accelerates cultural change and the creation of new (western middle-class) cultural values. The results of empirical studies are mixed, with some studies finding positive, others negative, and still others no relationship between quantity and quality. This paper extends the existing discussion by evaluating the evidence from a historical perspective. The time-series data for five presently developed countries and eighteen developing countries show that, prior to the attainment of primary gross enrollment ratios of about 70 or 80 percent, there appeared to be little relationship between levels or change in primary school enrollments and fertility. There were exceptions, but overall a fairly high level of educational development, as indicated by the level of primary enrollments, seemed to be important for a decline in fertility to take place. It is suggested in this paper that costs and financing arrangements, and parental aspirations for children's education may be important reasons behind the observed historical relationship. At early stages of development, parental aspirations are likely to be low, so that for most children parents desire only a few years of primary schooling. At this level of education, the costs, both direct and indirect, are also low. Moreover, the social organiza- tion in traditional societies is likely to be such that parents do not expect to bear the full cost of their children's schooling since they can usually rely on relatives and even older children for financial support. As a society modernizes, however, the inverse relationship between child schooling and parental fertility is likely to become stronger. The high level of primary school enrollments characteristic of such societies is probably symptomatic of
 rising returns to education, which :Lmplies a corresponding rising pay-off to inrestment in child quality. Parents are likely to plan for more years of education for their children, including possibly secondary and even higher education. This is likely to imply an escalating economic burden, since the opportunity cosst of children's eclucalt:ion at the post-primary ages is substantially higher than at the younlger ages. Also, as the process of development often weakens kinship tLes and sibling obligations, the cost of firancing schooling is likely to fall more fully on parents.  1. Introduction The purpose of this paper is to study the relationship between the schooling of children (as opposed to that of parents) and fertility change. Some attention will be paid to mortality change, although that is more likely to be a cause than an effect of changes in children's education. There already exists a strong body of evidence which notes a negative relation of mother's education to fertility and to child mortality [Cochrane, 1979, 1980; Behm, 1979; United Nations, 19821. The focus here will be less on differentials and more on trends over time, with attention being paid to declines in fertility and changes in school enrollment, schooling costs, compulsory schooling, costs and benefits of children and their schooling, and some other relevant factors, such as child labor laws, which affect fertility through the child. 2. Children's Schooling and Fertility Change 2.1 Preliminary Considerations The education or schooling of children is generally regarded as an investment in human capital, or child quality [Becker, 1975, 1981; Schultz, 1981]. Associated with this investment process are direct costs (e.g., expenditures on school fees, books, supplies, subsistence costs) and indirect costs, particularly foregone earnings (opportunity cost) of the child. Benefits are to be expected. They are not so easy to measure, but would include enhanced future welfare of the child, especially because of higher wages or earnings, as well as increased income to the family, if the child contributes to the family when he or she eventually enters the labor force.
 -2- Several important questions must be approached in the course of the inquiry: Who makes schooling decisions? Wrho finances schooling (i.e., parents or the government)? Why would parents or children invest in child q[uality? What is the relationship of school[ng to fertility and child mortality? What has been the historical and contemporary record on this? These topics form the basis for the present paper. 2.2 Theoretical Relationships and Supporting Evidence The literature on the demographic transition has often mentioned edcucation as an important aspect of the transition process [Notestein, 1954; 3eaver, 1975; Coale, 1973] Much attention has been paid to the existence of a negative relationship between parental education (especially education of i:he mother) and fertility ICochrane, 1979; Graff, 1979]. Much of the empirical work has dealt wi-th cross-sectional results, but some evidence irndicates that secular change in education may influence fertility decline [Stycos, 1977]. Education of parents also appears to affect differential childhood mortality [Cochrane, 1980; United Nations, 1982; Behm, 1979]. Another aspect operates through the education process by affecting :he costs and benefits of children. The fertility behavior of the parents, and possibly child mortalit:y in their families, are influenced by the costs of eclucating their children and by the perceived benefits of thatt education [Arnold, et. al., 1975; Ca]dwell, 1982, ch. 10]. Schooling has been associated witn modernizati-on and the demographic transition. Ansley Coale, in his discussion of the demographic transitions, notes: "[A] society was modern, in 1960, if at least 50 percent of the population lived in urban settlements of more than 20,000 persons, if more than 90 percent
 -3- of the female population at ages 6 to 13 was enrolled in school, and fewer than 30 percent of the labor force was engaged in agriculture, fishing and forestry. A society was traditional if less than 30 percent of its population lived in urban settlements of more than 20,000 persons, if fewer than 50 percent of females 6 to 13 were enrolled in school, and if more than 60 percent of the labor force was engaged in agriculture, fishing, or forestry." [Coale, 1973, p. 641 A modern society is one with low birth and death rates and a traditional society is one with high fertility and mortality. One problem with this viewpoint is that "threshold values" of these indicators seem to have changed over time. For example, Germany and Scandinavia had very high levels of literacy by 1870, but had undergone no sustained fertility decline. Examining historical evidence, Knodel and van de Walle [1979] found no evidence of a correlation between level of literacy and the date of onset of the fertility decline. Nevertheless, Caldwell has advanced the theory that fertility decline only sets in when the direction of net wealth flow changes from children to parents over to parents to children. "It is argued that the primary deter- minant of the timing of the onset of the fertility transition is the effect of mass education on the family economy. The direction of the wealth flow between generations is changed with the introduction of mass education. . . [Caldwell, 1982, p. 301]. He cites five mechanisms for this impact of mass education on parents' fertility behavior. First, the child's potential for work both inside and outside the family would be reduced (i.e., indirect costs to the family are increased). This is not only because of hours needed for school attendance and homework, but also changing attitudes of the child and the family toward traditional work at home. Second, education increases
 -4- direct costs to the family. These costs often go beyond fees, books, uniforms and supplies into improved general levels of clothing, nutrition, etc. Third, schooling, or rather the philosophy which underlies the instil:ution of mass education, changes the position of the child in the family andL in society. Rather than being regarded as a present productive resource within the family, the child is regarded as a future productive resource by society and, eventually, by the family. The status of dependent is reinforced and increased, and society passes laws to protect children (e.g., child labor and compulsory schooling laws). Fourth, mass education accelerates cultural change and the creation of new cultural values, particularly because the working class can now be reached th,rough their children. And finally, the schools serve as a major instrument for propagating Western m],ddle-class values [Caldwell, 1982, pp. 303-305]. In general, the first two mechanisms (via indirect and direct costs) are widely cited; whereas education as a means of creating, changing and diffusing values and norms is often considered, but n3t very systematically. Caldwell indeed believes that it is the last three value-related mechanisms wh-ich are more influential in turning the family economy from one in which childrenL are perceived as a net benefit to one in w-xich they are seen as a net cost. Another approach has been taken in recent years by economists who have constructed micro-economic, household decision-making moclels which incorporate a quantity-quality trade-off in childbearing [Becker, 1960, 1981, cla. 5; Becker and Lewis, 1973; Becker and Tomes, 1976; Willis, 1973; DeTray, 1973]. This literature draws on the notions of household procLuction functions anid human capital theory [Schultz, 1981; Becker, 1975; Michael and Becker, 1973]. In the simplest type of model [Beclker, 1981, pp. 103-104], the demand
 -5- for number of children (quantity) and child quality depends both on the shadow prices of quantity, quality, and other commodities, and "shadow income". Quantity and quality (the amount of human capital) of children interact inversely in demand functions, depending upon market prices and income. That is, an increase in quantity decreases demand for quality, both through the shadow income constraint and by raising the shadow price of quality. An increase in quality decreases demand for quantity by a similar mechanism. (See Appendix A for a brief description in more formal terms.) Although quantity and quality need not be close substitutes (and indeed cannot be if the system is to be stable in a range of plausible values), an increase in demand for one will decrease the demand for the other. This offers a probable reason for historical fertility decline in developed countries. "Several alternative explanations for large changes in fertility have been suggested, including the contraceptive revolution ushered in by the pill. . , but this cannot explain the large decline in births in the United States during the twenties or in Japan during the fifties. I am convinced that the most promising explanation is found in the interaction between quantity and quality of children, for it implies that the demand for children is highly responsive to price and perhaps to income, even when children have no close substitutes." [Becker, 1981, pp. 106-107] A basic conclusion of this model is that economic development and modernization, which usually increase demand for skilled labor relative to unskilled labor, raises rates of return on education and training, especially in urban areas. This lowers the marginal cost (and hence the shadow price) of child quality. As a consequence, demand for child quality increases, which interacts with quantity to reduce fertility. In addition, reductions in child mortality can reduce the marginal cost of child quality, which can, in turn, reduce fertility via the same mechanisms (see below).
 -6- In general, the basic model can be extended to anything which reduces the costs ol' child quality or increase the returns, including various governmental policies such as schooling, which affect human capital investments. Becker cites evidence [1981, p. 1111 that the empirical relationship between quantity and quality is usually negative, especially for developed countries. The Historical Experience of Developed Countries 3.1 Fertility and Mortality Trends The development process has, as one of its major characteristics, the transition from high to low Levels of fertility and mortality [Kuznets, 1966, pp. 40-56]. As a consequence, by definition all presently developed nations have achieved a demographic transition. From that developed group (Western and Northern Europe, Spain, Italy, the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe, the U.S., Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Israel and Japan), five countries were selected for description here: the United States, England and Wales, Germany, Sweden and Japan. The selection, was based on a desire to obtain good data for reasonably long time periods for relatively large countries. Japan is of interest as the most developed "non-Western" nation, while the United States is distinguished for its early fertility transition. Britain experienced the first industrial revolution [Landes, 1969, ch.2], Germany had a rapid fertility decline [Knodel, 1974] arLd Sweden had a long history of excellent demographic data. Other casess clearly could have been chosen, but those seemed to give a good range of experiences and contexts.

 - 64 - 4.5 Privatte Returns to Schooling Having considered the private cost of education, we now turn to examine its private returns to iLndividuals and their families. In calculating these returns, economists have generally used individuals' earnings as the yardstick of benefits associated with attending school. Clearly this approach is flawed,, as it discounts the fact that education provides a host of other not-easi.ly-quantified benefits, such as ability to appreciate literature and art better. However, since the focus of this paper is not on measurement, we shall merely note that rates of return calculated on the basis of earnings data represent lower bound evaluations of the total benefits to schooling. That individuals gain from attending school is hardly debatable; research findings corroborate casual observation that educated individuals earn more than those who are not. In a recent study, Psacharopoulos [1981] provided a compilation of rate-of-return data for over 40 countries. These data reveal that everywhere in the developing world, the private returns to education, particularly for primary schooling are generally high, and, almost without fail, exceed the 10 percent commonly associated with the opportunity cost of capital. Moreover, time series data, which are available only for USA ancL Colombia, indicate that these returns remain highly attractive over time despite the rapid expansion of education. The reason is because with development and technological change, the demand for educated labor keeps pace with the rapidly growing supply. Although individuals galn personally from being educated, the decision to enroll, particularly at the primary and secondary levels, is probably made by their parents, and not the individuals themselves. What are parents' motivations in sending a child to school? Clearly at one
 - 65 - level, it is because education is perceived to be a viable vehicle of upward social mobility for the child. Even if parents are less altruistic, the fact is that as society becomes technologically more complex, and as more people rely on urban employment for a livelihood, it becomes a necessity for children to be at least literate in order to survive economically. First, the connections between the education of children and the demand for chldren have been explored both in theory and in previous empirical work. Second, the relationship between changes in schooling and changes in fertility has also been studied. Finally, the association between education of children and fertility decline has been viewed, on a basic empirical level, historically for five presently developed countries and also for 18 developing countries since 1950. Some of the theory predicts a negative association of children's education and fertility. This stems largely from two directions, the human capital, quantity-quality tradeoff, extensively elaborated by Gary Becker, and the intergenerational transfer model of J.C. Caldwell. While these models are useful, they need to be subjected to modification based on specific circumstances. (See, for example, the qualifications noted by Mueller (1983)). The effect of schooling of children operates through direct and indirect (opportunity) costs as well as changes in expected future returns to education. The process of economic development and modernization generally raises the undiscounted returns to education. Direct private costs (in real terms) often decline, due to increased government intervention and financing of education. Indirect costs (foregone earnings of children) may rise, although compulsory schooling laws and child labor legislation can reduce these costs. In the earliest stages of development, during which investment in children is mainly primary schooling, there may be only a weak negative relationship, or even a positive relationship, between children's education and fertility. If price and/or income elasticities for child quality are
 - 72 - smaller than those for child quantity, if direct or indirect education costs are low, (e.g. if on:Ly young children attend primary school); if there are economies of scale in financing of education within the household (e.g. older children paLying for younger children); if child mortality i.s high; or if returns to education are relatively low, then the relationship can weaken or turn postitive. These conditions are more likely to prevail in low income agrarian societies than in hLgher income urban environnients. The data presented iLn tthis paper are consistent with the theory. Historically for developed countries and more recently for developing countries there seemed to have been little relationship between levels or change in primary school enrollments until primary gross enrollment ratios (GER's) reached a level of about 70-80% of children in the relevant age categories. There were exceptions (such as the United States in the nineteenth century and Thailand since 1960), but, overall, a high level of primary GER seems important to a decline in fertility. At earlier stages of developrment, with lower parental aspirations for education, most schooling consisting of only a few years of primary education, low direct ecoaomic burdens per child year of schooling, low opportunity costs for young children in school, and with older children or relatives often sharing direct costs, the relationship of schooling to fertility is likely to be weak. The direction and strength of the relationship depends both on economic and cultural conditions. When, however, a sociely reaches a certain level of development, with accompanying rising incomes and levels of urbanization, then the relationship seems to strengthen. It is likely that high levels of primary GER's are symptomatic of rising returns to education (and a
 - 73 - consequent decline in the price of child quality). At this point, many parents begin to plan for more years of children's education. The longer gestation period, together with rising unit costs at higher levels of education, imply that anticipated child quality investments involve an escalating economic burden. Kinship ties and sibling obligations often change and weaken in the process of development, placing the direct costs of children more fully on parents. Factors leading to declining costs of education, such as compulsory schooling and child labor laws (operating on indirect costs) as well as increased public support of education (operating on direct costs), would most likely operate at the primary level than at the secondary level. Once parents begin to demand greater amounts of education for their children, which is more likely to occur at higher levels of income and development, the conflict between large families and child quality becomes greater. Education costs increase rapidly, particularly because the opportunity cost of children's education is much higher for children in secondary school ages, but also because direct secondary school costs are more likely to fall on parents and families. Alternatively, under Caldwell's model, as children begin to obtain more secondary education, the direction of the net flow of resources between parents and children changes in favor of children, and parents begin to reduce fertility. This is again consistent with the data which indicate fertility decline associated with rising secondary GER's, in a situation in which universal primary education was either already established or being approached. A recent study by Anker (1978) has produced results consistent with the quantity-quality tradeoff. The study used country level data from 69 LDC's for 1968-70, measured child quality investment as the
 - 74 - secondary school enrollment rate, and estimated a simultaneous structural model. His two stage leasi: squares estimates of the model indicated that, ceteris paribus, a ten percent rise in the secondary school enrollment ratio would be accompanied by a 1.2 percent drop in fertility. This relationship was statistically significant at a ten percent level. The study also noted that, at early stages of development, rising life expectatiorn at birth and falling female labor force participation tended partially to offset the negative effect on fertility of rising adult literacy, school enrollment, aLnd non-agricultural employment. At intermediate levels of development, these relationships became more uniformly negative. This paper has been exploratory and descriptive in nature. It attempts to delineate the relationship of demand for children and fertility to the education of children, both at the primary and the secondary levels. Although the present findings are tentative, they are suggestive and indicate a strategy for additional research on this topic.

doc.repnme: Schooling and demand for children : historical perspectives
doc.abstracts: Theory predicts that schooling of children exerts a negative effect on parental fertility. Results of empirical studies related to this are mixed. This paper extends the existing discussion by evaluating the evidence from a historical perspective. The time-series data for five presently developed countries and eighteen developing countries show that, with some exceptions, overall a fairly high level of educational development seemed to be important for a decline in fertility to take place. It is suggested that costs and financing arrangements and parental aspirations for children's education may be important reasons behind the observed historical relationship. As a society modernizes the inverse relationship between child schooling and parental fertility is likely to become stronger. The high level of primary school enrollments characteristic of such societies is probably symptomatic of rising returns to education, which implies a corresponding rising payoff to investment in child quality.
